awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Revolutionizing Propylene Production via Oxidative Dehydrogenation and CO2 Dissociation in Tandem
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of catalytic routes for converting lower alkanes to olefins is a challenging problem with high potential payoff due to the vast shale gas resources that have recently become available. The overarching goal of this project is to revolutionize propylene production from alkanes through an innovative tandem catalytic reaction scheme that improves overall conversion and selectivity. The project is based on a potentially transformative approach where new paradigms in reaction mechanisms guide catalyst synthesis. A hierarchical framework will be developed for rational design and characterization of catalysts with significant potential broader impact in the energy, petrochemical and chemical sectors of the US industry.

The main objective of this project is to develop a new class of bifunctional catalysts based on sub-stoichiometric nanophase metal oxides that will work in a tandem reaction scheme, where oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes and carbon dioxide reduction, via dissociative adsorption, will occur simultaneously without producing syngas. The proposed novel tandem reaction scheme has the potential to intensify on-purpose propylene production by preventing side reactions, such as coke formation, and further aromatization of propylene. A new facile synthesis method for producing oxygen-deficient anatase nanosheet catalysts is proposed by utilizing highly amorphous solubilized cellulose as a sacrificial template. The proposed experimental framework is based on optical reactor prototyping and Operando spectroscopy, where the molecular structure and reactivity of the metal oxide catalysts are studied simultaneously in a single optical cell by time- and spatially-resolved Raman spectroscopy under real working conditions. Integration of research and education is focused towards modernizing the chemical reaction engineering curriculum with teaching modules on Operando spectroscopy. Outreach efforts are aimed at engaging K-12 students, including underrepresented minorities, by developing a freeware computer game that teaches principles of molecular symmetry and spectroscopy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This program aimed to develop a fundamental understanding of the oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes using CO₂ as a mild oxidant, with a specific focus on synthesizing and characterizing a range of metal oxide-based catalytic systems derived from reducible oxides. Key outcomes include the development of novel physicochemical characterization methods, kinetic models for propane ODH, and open-access tools for spectroscopic education.

A significant early achievement was the development of a novel method to synthesize titanium dioxide (TiO₂) with enhanced structural and thermal properties using molten salt hydrates (MSH) as the synthesis medium. This approach produced TiO₂ with high surface area, mesoporosity, and thermal stability, featuring thin, flake-like morphologies with adjustable thickness. By carefully controlling the salt-to-water and salt-to-precursor ratios, we were able to precisely control particle aggregation into two-dimensional structures. The crystalline phase, predominantly anatase or brookite, was determined by the LiBr-to-water ratio, highlighting the importance of synthesis parameters. These insights improve our understanding of TiO₂ synthesis and offer scalable solutions for catalytic applications.

Next, we investigated propane oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) with CO₂ using Fe-doped CeO₂ catalysts, leveraging cerium oxide's high oxygen mobility and storage capacity. Fe was uniformly incorporated into the ceria lattice via co-precipitation. Catalytic testing revealed that moderate Fe loading optimally balanced propane conversion and propylene selectivity while minimizing cracking. Deactivation studies identified coke deposition and structural changes, such as CeO₂ sintering and Fe migration, as key challenges at low and high Fe loadings.

Following this, we developed a comprehensive framework to study the molecular configuration of (MoOx)n species on anatase-TiO₂ and CeO₂–TiO₂ supports. Using equilibrium deposition filtration, we achieved molecular-level control of active molybdenum sites at sub-monolayer loadings. Through in situ Raman spectrokinetics coupled with isotopic 18O₂/16O₂ exchange, we found that species distribution is strongly influenced by precursor pH, with mono-oxo configurations dominating. Transient operando spectroscopy uncovered site-specific oxygen reactivity, showing sequential removal of surface oxygen from terminal (Mo═O) sites, followed by Mo-O-Support bond cleavage.

Our work also advanced the use of diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopy (DPR) by integrating the exponentially modified Gaussian (EMG) function to enhance derivative peak fitting for complex metal oxide mixtures. This enhancement expanded DPR's applicability to oxides like titania, ceria, and other catalytic semiconductors.

A major contribution of this project was enhancing spectroscopic education by developing computational tools that make learning more accessible and engaging. We created Porchlight, a Python-based application that enables easy application of spectral preprocessing techniques with immediate results, providing an affordable alternative to commercial software. This tool, along with Jupyter notebooks, makes spectroscopic analysis widely available to students, trainees, and users, integrating preprocessing into curricula and providing early exposure to data-handling techniques that accelerate learning.

Additionally, we developed a MATLAB-based program to introduce students to spectral parameter estimation for Raman spectroscopy, optimizing data collection for high signal-to-noise ratios. This tool improves students’ ability to interpret spectral data while combining chemistry with computational techniques, fostering interdisciplinary learning. By bridging theoretical coursework and hands-on experience, this initiative prepares students for roles in industry and research, particularly in material characterization, reaction monitoring, and process control.
